results.title: The Queen in Canada, 1964
results.creator_credit: Gordon Sparling, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A hundred years earlier, the Fathers of Confederation gathered in Charlottetown, Prince Edward Island, to discuss the idea of a united Canada. In October, 1964, Queen Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh came to commemorate that event and the conference at Quebec City that followed it.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gordon Sparling, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: The Queen in Australia
results.brief_description: In 1954, recently crowned Queen Elizabeth II and HRH the Duke of Edinburgh embarked on a two month tour of Australia.

constellations_other.name: Royalty, royalty, royalty
constellations_other.description: Fascination with the royal family has persisted over the years, as seen through newsreels, documentaries, films, TV shows, tabloid news and satire.

results.description: In 1954, recently crowned Queen Elizabeth II and HRH the Duke of Edinburgh embarked on a two month tour of Australia. It involved some 10,000 miles of travel by air and 4,000 miles by land and sea. The couple visited every state in the nation, and turned up at all sorts of events, from tennis at Kooyong to steel mills in Newcastle to woodchopping at Wagga to the Flying Doctor Service Service at Broken Hill. The film production arm of the federal government - the Film Division of the News and Information Bureau of the Department of the Interior - decided to cover the tour in 35mm colour film, sending the footage to England for processing and editing. Six weeks after the tour ended, the film was finished and became the first feature-length Australian film shot and financed by Australians in colour to be given a theatrical release.
description_for_label: In 1954, recently crowned Queen Elizabeth II and HRH the Duke of Edinburgh embarked on a two month tour of Australia. It involved some 10,000 miles of travel by air and 4,000 miles by land and sea. The couple visited every state in the nation, and turned up at all sorts of events, from tennis at Kooyong to steel mills in Newcastle to woodchopping at Wagga to the Flying Doctor Service Service at Broken Hill. The film production arm of the federal government - the Film Division of the News and Information Bureau of the Department of the Interior - decided to cover the tour in 35mm colour film, sending the footage to England for processing and editing. Six weeks after the tour ended, the film was finished and became the first feature-length Australian film shot and financed by Australians in colour to be given a theatrical release.

results.title: The Queen in Australia
results.creator_credit: Stanley Hawes and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: The Queen in Australia is a landmark in Australian history. It not only records the first visit by a reigning monarch to Australia, it was also the first colour, feature-length documentary made in this country. This historic program provides nationwide coverage of the 1954 Royal Tour by Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II and HRH the Duke of Edinburgh - a two-month journey that took in every facet of Australian life: garden parties at Government House, dancers at the Tivoli, racing at Randwick, tennis at Kooyong with Rosewall and Hoad, cricket with the Don, even a meeting with Papua New Guinean tribal chiefs. The young royals visited every state in the nation, and the result is a remarkable and revealing insight into our nation in the 1950s.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stanley Hawes and Australian National Film Board

images.caption: The Queen in Australia (Stanley Hawes) still

results.title: The Queen Goes West
results.creator_credit: Christine Olsen, Curtis Levy and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: It was the outback’s greatest day! A big mob of cattlemen, shearers, stockmen and women gathered together to give Her Majesty the Queen a great Aussie welcome. We look at the lives of these descendants of the outback pioneers and catch the spirit of the Australian bush. Country people devoted a lot of hard yakka to make the opening of the Australian Stockman’s Hall of Fame a big success. This warm and affectionate view of their lives and this great occasion is a tribute to the enduring spirit of outback adventure.

results.title: The Queen and Prince Philip
results.creator_credit: Ann Turner, Michael Gill and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Royal Heritage the Story of Britains Builders and Collectors”.
Shows various aspects of the royal lives with special emphasis on their responsibilities towards the royal heritage of treasures and collections and the preservation of historic royal buildings. Also shows the Queen and Prince Phillip with their children and grandchildren.

results.title: The Queen's Plate
results.creator_credit: John Howe and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film describes the history of Canada’s horse-racing classic, the Queen’s Plate, and the rearing of a contender from its birth to its entry in the peak event. Queen Elizabeth presents the trophy. (Award: Cortina D’Ampezzo.)
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Howe and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: The Queen's Navy
results.creator_credit: Derek Mayne, Frank Wells and Gaumont British Specialised Film Unit
results.brief_description: A general picture of the Royal Navy pointing out that its efficiency as a fighting force comes from mastery of self through discipline and training and mastery of science. A picture of the royal Navy, stressing that its efficiency and effectiveness rest upon three things, mastery of sea, self and science. The sea has been mastered by the inherent skill in handling ships and a knowledge of the ways of the sea traditional in British people. Mastery of self is achieved through discipline, the result of self-confidence and control, required in every training establishment. Finally mastery of science is needed, for the Royal navy of today is a highly technical force, and employs many scientific devices and weapons.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Derek Mayne, Frank Wells and Gaumont British Specialised Film Unit

results.title: The Queen's Corgi
results.creator_credit: nWave Pictures, Belga Productions, Ben Stassen, John R. Smith, Rob Sprackling, Caroline Van Iseghem and Vincent Kesteloot
results.brief_description: When the Queen’s favourite dog, Rex, becomes lost, he must make new friends and embrace new adventures in order to find his way back to the palace.

constellations_other.name: Royalty, royalty, royalty
constellations_other.description: Fascination with the royal family has persisted over the years, as seen through newsreels, documentaries, films, TV shows, tabloid news and satire.

results.creator_credit_for_label: nWave Pictures, Belga Productions, Ben Stassen, John R. Smith, Rob Sprackling, Caroline Van Iseghem and Vincent Kesteloot
results.description: Since his arrival at Buckingham palace, Rex lives a life of luxury. Top dog, he has superseded his three fellow Corgis in Her Majesty’s heart. His arrogance can be quite irritating. When he causes a diplomatic incident during an official dinner with the President of the United States, he falls into disgrace. Betrayed by one of his peers, Rex becomes a stray dog in the streets of London. How can he redeem himself? In love, he will find the resources to surpass himself in the face of great danger…

results.title: The Queen
results.creator_credit: BIM Distribuzione, Granada Film Productions, Scott Rudin Productions, Future Films, Pathé Pictures International, Pathé Renn Productions, Canal+, France 3 Cinéma, Consolata Boyle, Alan MacDonald, Andy Harries, Stephen Frears, Christine Langan, Peter Morgan and Tracey Seaward
results.headline_credit: France, Italy, United Kingdom and United States of America, 2006
results.brief_description: The Queen is an intimate behind the scenes glimpse at the interaction between HM Elizabeth II and Prime Minister Tony Blair during their struggle, following the death of Diana, to reach a compromise between what was a private tragedy for the Royal family and the public’s demand for an overt display of mourning.
